question_title: Will North Korea conduct a nuclear test before May 1, 2026?
summary: North Korea has been technically ready to conduct a 7th nuclear test since at least 2022 (Tunnel No. 3 at Punggye-ri is operational), but has chosen not to for 8+ years since September 2017. The unconditional base rate is ~2.6%/month (~7.7% over 3 months), but multiple factors reduce this: November 2025 satellite imagery shows no imminent test preparations (no instruments, power lines, vehicles, or personnel), North Korea's military focus has been on missile testing and production rather than nuclear testing, and the 8+ year pause despite readiness indicates political constraints are the binding factor. The Workers' Party Congress in February 2026 and escalating nuclear rhetoric provide some upside risk, but diplomatic considerations (stalled Trump-Kim talks, Russia/China relationships) and the absence of concrete preparation indicators keep probability low.

factors.description: No satellite indicators of imminent test preparations at Punggye-ri as of November 2025 - no instruments, power lines, cables, vehicles, or personnel detected despite Tunnel No. 3 being operational
8+ year gap since last nuclear test (Sept 2017) despite technical readiness since 2022, indicating strong political/strategic constraints against testing
Historical base rate: 6 tests in ~228 months = 2.63%/month, giving ~7.7% over the 3-month window - low baseline probability
North Korea's military focus in 2025-2026 has been on missile testing, production expansion, and delivery systems rather than nuclear warhead testing
Workers' Party Congress expected February 2026 with new 5-year defense plan announcements - could provide political occasion for nuclear test
Kim Jong Un's escalating rhetoric about 'unlimited and sustained' nuclear weapons development and nuclear force expansion
Stalled Trump-Kim diplomacy and NK rejection of US talks reduces diplomatic deterrent to testing, but also reduces provocation incentive
'Nothing Ever Happens' adjustment - nuclear tests are dramatic, high-profile events that forecasters tend to overestimate
